title: Matthew Chapter 23 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Matthew chapter 23 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Matthew Chapter 23 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Matthew Chapter 23.

questions.question: Who did Jesus say sit in Moses' seat?
questions.correctAnswer: The scribes and the Pharisees
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:2 states that the scribes and the Pharisees sit in Moses' seat.

questions.question: What did Jesus say you should do with what the scribes and Pharisees bid you observe?
questions.correctAnswer: Observe and do it
questions.explanation: In Matthew 23:3, Jesus instructs to observe and do what the scribes and Pharisees bid, but not to follow their works.

questions.question: What kind of burdens did the scribes and Pharisees lay on men's shoulders?
questions.correctAnswer: Heavy and grievous burdens
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:4 states that they bind heavy burdens and grievous to be borne on men's shoulders.

questions.question: For what reason do the scribes and Pharisees do all their works, according to Matthew 23?
questions.correctAnswer: To be seen of men
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:5 explains that all their works are done to be seen by men.

questions.question: What do the scribes and Pharisees love at feasts and in synagogues?
options: The uppermost rooms and chief seats
questions.correctAnswer: The uppermost rooms and chief seats
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:6 states they love the uppermost rooms at feasts and the chief seats in the synagogues.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus said to call no man your father upon the earth because one is your Father in heaven.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:9 clearly states not to call any man your father on earth, for one is your Father in heaven.

questions.question: According to Matthew 23, who is the one Master?
questions.correctAnswer: Christ
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:10 mentions that only one is Master, even Christ.

questions.question: Who shall be greatest among you according to Jesus?
questions.correctAnswer: The servant
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:11 says the greatest among you shall be your servant.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Whosoever shall exalt himself shall be ______; and he that shall humble himself shall be exalted.'
questions.correctAnswer: abased
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:12 teaches that whoever exalts himself shall be abased, and whoever humbles himself shall be exalted.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus called the scribes and Pharisees hypocrites because they shut up the kingdom of heaven against men.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In Matthew 23:13, Jesus calls them hypocrites for shutting the kingdom of heaven against men.

questions.question: What is one of the accusations Jesus makes against the scribes and Pharisees regarding widows?
questions.correctAnswer: They devour widows' houses
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:14 states that they devour widows' houses and make long prayers for pretense.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about those who make one proselyte according to Matthew 23?
options: They make him twofold more the child of hell
They make him a great teacher
They teach him the law correctly
questions.correctAnswer: They make him twofold more the child of hell
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:15 condemns them for making proselytes who become more wicked than themselves.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus says to be called Rabbi because one is your Master.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:8 says do not be called Rabbi for one is your Master, even Christ.

questions.question: What does Jesus compare the scribes and Pharisees to in verse 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Whited sepulchres
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:27 compares them to whited sepulchres, beautiful outward but full of dead men's bones inside.

questions.question: What will happen to the generation that killed the prophets, according to Matthew 23:36?
options: All these things shall come upon this generation
questions.correctAnswer: All these things shall come upon this generation
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:36 declares that all the consequences will come upon that generation.

medium.title: Matthew Chapter 23 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Matthew Chapter 23 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Matthew 23 teach us about humility in leadership within the church?
options: The greatest should be the servant
Leaders should seek the highest honor
Leaders must demand respect by titles
Humility is not important for leaders
questions.correctAnswer: The greatest should be the servant
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches in Matthew 23:11-12 that the greatest among believers is the one who serves others and that those who exalt themselves will be humbled, while those who humble themselves will be exalted. This emphasizes humility as a key virtue for leadership.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with hypocrisy in their spiritual life. Based on Matthew 23, what biblical truth would you share?
options: True righteousness comes from the heart, not just outward appearance
Outward religious acts are the most important
Hypocrisy is acceptable if others are impressed
One should only focus on ritual purity
questions.correctAnswer: True righteousness comes from the heart, not just outward appearance
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:25-28 warns against being clean only on the outside while being full of hypocrisy and iniquity within. Jesus compares such people to whited sepulchres that appear beautiful outwardly but are inwardly full of uncleanness, teaching the importance of inner holiness.

questions.question: What does Matthew 23 say about the practice of tithing and its relation to justice, mercy, and faith?
options: They should practice justice, mercy, and faith along with tithing
Tithing alone is sufficient for righteousness
Justice and mercy are less important than tithing
questions.correctAnswer: They should practice justice, mercy, and faith along with tithing
questions.explanation: In Matthew 23:23, Jesus rebukes the scribes and Pharisees for paying tithes on small herbs but neglecting the weightier matters of the law: judgment (justice), mercy, and faith. He emphasizes doing these important things without neglecting the others.

questions.question: How does Matthew 23 encourage believers to handle titles like 'Rabbi' or 'Father' in their fellowship?
options: Do not be called Rabbi or Father because you have one Master and one Father in heaven
Everyone should seek to be called Rabbi
Titles are essential for spiritual authority
Only elders should be called Father
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be called Rabbi or Father because you have one Master and one Father in heaven
questions.explanation: Verses 8-10 teach that believers should not seek honorific titles such as Rabbi or Father because Christ alone is the Master and God alone is the Father, promoting humility and brotherhood in the community.

questions.question: A believer is overwhelmed with burdens from religious rules. Based on Matthew 23, how should they view such burdens?
options: Be cautious of leaders who lay heavy burdens but do not help carry them
Add more rules to become holier
Ignore all teachings from religious leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Be cautious of leaders who lay heavy burdens but do not help carry them
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:4 describes how the scribes and Pharisees lay heavy burdens on others but do not help carry them, warning believers to be discerning about legalistic demands that lack compassion and support.

questions.question: What warning does Matthew 23 give about seeking honor and recognition in religious service?
options: Avoid doing works just to be seen by others
Always seek public recognition for your work
Make your garments as elaborate as possible
Ask to be greeted loudly in public
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid doing works just to be seen by others
questions.explanation: In Matthew 23:5-7, Jesus rebukes the Pharisees for performing their works to be seen by men, such as enlarging phylacteries and loving the uppermost seats and greetings, teaching believers to serve humbly without seeking public acclaim.

questions.question: According to Matthew 23, what is the danger of focusing on minor religious details while neglecting weightier matters?
options: It leads to spiritual blindness and hypocrisy
It is the highest form of righteousness
It is recommended for spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: It leads to spiritual blindness and hypocrisy
questions.explanation: Jesus calls the Pharisees blind guides in Matthew 23:23-24 for tithing small herbs but neglecting justice, mercy, and faith, illustrating how focusing on trivial details while ignoring core principles leads to hypocrisy.

questions.question: What does Matthew 23 teach about the heart attitude behind prayer and religious acts?
options: Prayer should be genuine, not for show
Long prayers make one more righteous
Prayer is only about public display
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer should be genuine, not for show
questions.explanation: In Matthew 23:14, Jesus condemns the Pharisees for making long prayers as a pretence while exploiting widows, highlighting that sincerity in prayer is essential rather than mere outward display.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 23 teaches that believers should seek to be called 'Rabbi' to demonstrate spiritual authority.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jesus instructs in Matthew 23:8 not to be called Rabbi because there is only one Master, Christ, emphasizing humility rather than seeking titles.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 23 encourages believers to cleanse the inside first so that the outside will be clean as well.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:26 teaches that spiritual cleansing must begin within the heart to result in true outward holiness, contrasting superficial cleanliness with inner purity.

questions.question: How does Matthew 23 describe the behavior of those who persecute prophets and righteous people, and what lesson does it teach about perseverance?
options: Persecutors fulfill the sins of past generations; believers should persevere in faith
Persecution is rare and should be avoided at all costs
Persecution is a sign God has abandoned His people
questions.correctAnswer: Persecutors fulfill the sins of past generations; believers should persevere in faith
questions.explanation: Verses 34-36 describe how persecutors continue the legacy of killing prophets, showing the ongoing spiritual battle and encouraging believers to remain faithful despite opposition.

questions.question: A believer is confused about how to prioritize religious duties and acts of kindness. According to Matthew 23, what balance should they maintain?
options: Do justice, mercy, and faith while not neglecting small acts like tithing
Focus only on tithing, ignoring mercy and faith
Only practice mercy and ignore the law
Religious duties are more important than kindness
questions.correctAnswer: Do justice, mercy, and faith while not neglecting small acts like tithing
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:23 emphasizes that believers should uphold the weightier matters of the law such as judgment, mercy, and faith, but not neglect tithing, teaching balanced obedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jesus compares outwardly righteous but inwardly sinful people to ________ which appear beautiful outwardly but are full of dead men's bones inside.
questions.correctAnswer: whited sepulchres
questions.explanation: In Matthew 23:27, Jesus uses the metaphor of whited sepulchres to illustrate those who appear righteous outwardly but are inwardly full of hypocrisy and uncleanness.

questions.question: How does Matthew 23 instruct believers to view swearing by the temple or the altar?
options: Swearing by the temple or altar is swearing by all that they represent
Swearing by the gold of the temple is more binding than by the temple itself
Only swearing by gifts is acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: Swearing by the temple or altar is swearing by all that they represent
questions.explanation: Verses 16-22 explain that swearing by the temple or altar is effectively swearing by everything associated with them, emphasizing the seriousness of oaths made in God's name.

questions.question: What does Matthew 23 teach about the danger of seeking positions of honor in religious settings?
options: Seeking the uppermost rooms and chief seats is condemned
Positions of honor guarantee spiritual favor
One should always seek the best seats to teach
Religious honor is more important than humility
questions.correctAnswer: Seeking the uppermost rooms and chief seats is condemned
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:6-7 criticizes the Pharisees for loving the best places at feasts and in synagogues, teaching that humility should replace the desire for status in spiritual life.

hard.title: Matthew Chapter 23 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Matthew Chapter 23.

questions.question: In Matthew 23, Jesus criticizes the scribes and Pharisees for sitting in Moses' seat. What does this position symbolize?
questions.correctAnswer: Authority to teach the Law
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:2 indicates that the scribes and Pharisees 'sit in Moses' seat,' which symbolizes their authoritative role in interpreting and teaching the Mosaic Law to the people.

questions.question: According to Matthew 23, what are the scribes and Pharisees criticized for doing in regards to the burdens they place on others?
options: Laying heavy burdens and not helping to bear them
Encouraging people to rest and find peace
Teaching only what they themselves practice
questions.correctAnswer: Laying heavy burdens and not helping to bear them
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:4 describes how the scribes and Pharisees 'bind heavy burdens and grievous to be borne, and lay them on men's shoulders; but they themselves will not move them with one of their fingers,' showing their hypocrisy.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Pharisees making their phylacteries broad and enlarging the borders of their garments?
options: To be seen and honored by men
To protect themselves from evil spirits
questions.correctAnswer: To be seen and honored by men
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:5 explains that the Pharisees do all their works to be seen of men, exemplified by making their phylacteries broad and enlarging garment borders as a display of piety for human admiration.

questions.question: What warning does Jesus give about the use of titles such as 'Rabbi' and 'Father' in Matthew 23?
options: Only God is the true Master and Father
Titles should be given generously to leaders
Titles are unimportant in the kingdom of heaven
One should seek honor through titles
questions.correctAnswer: Only God is the true Master and Father
questions.explanation: In Matthew 23:8-9, Jesus instructs not to be called Rabbi or Father on earth because there is one Master (Christ) and one Father in heaven, emphasizing God's unique authority.

questions.question: In Matthew 23, Jesus states, 'he that is greatest among you shall be your ______.' What is the missing word?
questions.correctAnswer: servant
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:11 reveals a radical inversion of worldly status: 'he that is greatest among you shall be your servant,' emphasizing humility and servant leadership in the kingdom of God.

questions.question: Which of the following themes does Jesus emphasize as more important than tithing mint, anise, and cummin?
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment, mercy, and faith
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:23 criticizes the Pharisees for tithing small herbs while neglecting 'weightier matters of the law, judgment, mercy, and faith,' highlighting the priority of ethical over ritualistic observance.

questions.question: What is the literary device used in Matthew 23:27-28 when Jesus compares the scribes and Pharisees to 'whited sepulchres'?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:27-28 uses a simile by saying they are 'like unto whited sepulchres,' which appear beautiful outwardly but are full of dead men's bones inside, illustrating their hypocrisy.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus condemns the scribes and Pharisees in Matthew 23 for shutting the kingdom of heaven against men, neither entering themselves nor allowing others to enter.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:13 explicitly states Jesus' woe to the scribes and Pharisees for shutting up the kingdom of heaven against men, highlighting their obstructive hypocrisy.

questions.question: What does Jesus accuse the scribes and Pharisees of doing to proselytes in Matthew 23:15?
options: Making them twofold more the child of hell
questions.correctAnswer: Making them twofold more the child of hell
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:15 condemns the scribes and Pharisees for traveling extensively to make one proselyte, only to make that proselyte worse than themselves in spiritual terms.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'ye serpents, ye generation of vipers' in Matthew 23:33?
options: It is a metaphor for their deceitfulness and danger
It is a reference to their origin
questions.correctAnswer: It is a metaphor for their deceitfulness and danger
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:33 uses the strong metaphor comparing the scribes and Pharisees to venomous snakes, emphasizing their corrupt and harmful nature.

questions.question: Which Old Testament figure's blood does Jesus mention in Matthew 23 as being on the hands of the scribes and Pharisees?
questions.correctAnswer: Abel
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:35 refers to the righteous blood shed from Abel to Zacharias, showing continuity in prophetic rejection and violence against God's messengers.

questions.question: What is the cultural significance of Jesus’ lament over Jerusalem in Matthew 23:37, using the image of a hen gathering her chicks?
options: It expresses a maternal protective instinct and desire to save
It is a common agricultural metaphor for punishment
It symbolizes the destruction of the temple
It represents a call to military revolt
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses a maternal protective instinct and desire to save
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:37 uses the hen gathering her chicks imagery to convey Jesus’ deep yearning to protect Jerusalem’s people despite their rejection of the prophets.

questions.question: In Matthew 23, Jesus mentions the scribes and Pharisees building tombs for the prophets but being guilty of what?
options: Being children of those who killed the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Being children of those who killed the prophets
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:29-31 points out the hypocrisy of honoring the prophets' tombs while being spiritually and historically complicit in their murders.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jesus tells the scribes and Pharisees to 'cleanse first that which is within the cup and platter, that the outside of them may be clean also.' This is found in which verse?
questions.correctAnswer: Matthew 23:26
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:26 uses this metaphor to emphasize internal purity over external appearance, highlighting the necessity of inward righteousness.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus declares that the scribes and Pharisees will not see Him again until they say, 'Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord.'
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:39 concludes the chapter with Jesus stating that they will not see Him until they acknowledge Him with this Messianic blessing, pointing to future recognition.

theological.title: Matthew Chapter 23 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Matthew Chapter 23 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Matthew 23:3, how are believers instructed to relate to the teachings of the scribes and Pharisees?
options: Observe what they teach but do not imitate their works
Ignore both their teachings and works
Follow their works but not their teachings
questions.correctAnswer: Observe what they teach but do not imitate their works
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:3 instructs to observe and do what the scribes and Pharisees teach, but not to follow their hypocritical practices. This aligns with Jesus' emphasis on internal righteousness over external show (Isaiah 29:13, Jeremiah 7:8, Luke 6:46, James 1:22).

questions.question: What is the main reason Jesus condemns the scribes and Pharisees in Matthew 23:13?
options: They shut the kingdom of heaven against men
They give generously to the poor
questions.correctAnswer: They shut the kingdom of heaven against men
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:13 condemns the scribes and Pharisees for hindering access to God's kingdom, neither entering themselves nor allowing others to enter. This reflects Old Testament warnings against false teachers blocking God's way (Isaiah 5:8, Ezekiel 22:26, 2 Peter 2:1, Revelation 22:15).

questions.question: In Matthew 23:11, what does Jesus say about the greatest among His followers?
options: The greatest shall be your servant
The greatest shall rule over many
The greatest shall be honored by all
questions.correctAnswer: The greatest shall be your servant
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches servant leadership in Matthew 23:11, emphasizing humility and service as marks of true greatness, consistent with Philippians 2:5-8, Mark 10:43-45, John 13:12-17, and 1 Peter 5:5-6.

questions.question: What does Jesus warn will happen to those who exalt themselves, according to Matthew 23:12?
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be abased
questions.explanation: Matthew 23:12 teaches the principle of divine reversal where self-exaltation leads to humiliation, and humility leads to exaltation. This reflects Proverbs 3:34, James 4:6, Luke 14:11, and 1 Peter 5:5.

questions.question: According to Matthew 23:23, what three 'weightier matters' of the law do the scribes and Pharisees neglect?
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment, mercy, and faith
questions.explanation: Jesus rebukes them in Matthew 23:23 for meticulous tithing but neglecting justice, mercy, and faithfulness, aligning with Micah 6:8, Hosea 6:6, Amos 5:24, and Matthew 9:13.

questions.question: What metaphor does Jesus use in Matthew 23:27 to describe the hypocrisy of the scribes and Pharisees?
questions.correctAnswer: Whited sepulchres
questions.explanation: They are likened to whited sepulchres, beautiful outside but full of dead bones and uncleanness inside, symbolizing external righteousness with internal corruption (Ezekiel 36:25-27, Isaiah 64:6, Romans 2:28-29, 1 Corinthians 3:13).

questions.question: In Matthew 23:9, why does Jesus instruct not to call anyone on earth 'father'?
options: Because there is only one Father in heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Because there is only one Father in heaven
questions.explanation: Jesus emphasizes God's unique fatherhood in Matthew 23:9, affirming divine sovereignty and rejecting titles that may foster human exaltation, consistent with Deuteronomy 32:6, Isaiah 63:16, John 20:17, and Romans 8:15.

questions.question: What sin is highlighted in Matthew 23:14 that results in greater damnation for the scribes and Pharisees?
options: Devouring widows' houses and making long prayers for show
Committing blasphemy against the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Devouring widows' houses and making long prayers for show
questions.explanation: They exploit vulnerable widows while using prayer as a pretense (Matthew 23:14), showing hypocrisy and injustice, reflecting Jeremiah 7:6-7, Isaiah 1:23, Luke 20:47, and James 1:27.

questions.question: How does Jesus describe the scribes and Pharisees' proselytizing efforts in Matthew 23:15?
options: They make converts twofold more the children of hell
They bring many to true faith
questions.correctAnswer: They make converts twofold more the children of hell
questions.explanation: Jesus condemns their efforts as leading converts deeper into sin (Matthew 23:15), indicative of false teaching and spiritual harm, paralleling 2 Timothy 3:13, Jude 1:12-13, 2 Peter 2:1-3, and Romans 16:17-18.

questions.question: What teaching error about oaths does Jesus expose in Matthew 23:16-22?
options: They prioritize oaths by gold over the temple's sanctity
They require oaths only on the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: They prioritize oaths by gold over the temple's sanctity
questions.explanation: Jesus exposes their blind error valuing material gold more than the temple's holiness (Matthew 23:16-22), teaching proper reverence for sacred things, consistent with Leviticus 19:12, Numbers 30:2, James 5:12, and Hebrews 8:1-2.

questions.question: According to Matthew 23:25-26, what must be cleansed first for true purity?
options: The inside, so the outside may be clean
questions.correctAnswer: The inside, so the outside may be clean
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches inner purity precedes external cleanliness (Matthew 23:25-26), a theme echoed in Psalm 51:10, Proverbs 4:23, 1 Samuel 16:7, and 2 Corinthians 7:1.

questions.question: Why does Jesus call the scribes and Pharisees 'serpents' and a 'generation of vipers' in Matthew 23:33?
options: Because of their deceit and the difficulty to escape damnation
questions.correctAnswer: Because of their deceit and the difficulty to escape damnation
questions.explanation: The metaphor in Matthew 23:33 emphasizes their dangerous deceit and certain judgment, consistent with Genesis 3:1-15, Exodus 7:9-12, John 8:44, and Romans 3:13-14.

questions.question: What eschatological warning is given in Matthew 23:36 about the generation Jesus was addressing?
options: All these judgments will come upon this generation
They will inherit the kingdom immediately
They will be exempt from judgment
questions.correctAnswer: All these judgments will come upon this generation
questions.explanation: Jesus pronounces impending judgment on the generation (Matthew 23:36), echoing themes of divine justice in Psalm 37:28, Ezekiel 18:20, Hebrews 10:30, and Revelation 6:10-11.

questions.question: In Matthew 23:37, how does Jesus describe His desire for Jerusalem's people?
options: He longs to gather them like a hen gathers her chicks
He wishes to punish them immediately
He wants to leave them alone
He plans to abandon them forever
questions.correctAnswer: He longs to gather them like a hen gathers her chicks
questions.explanation: Jesus expresses tender compassion and desire to protect Jerusalem's children (Matthew 23:37), fulfilling God's heart described in Deuteronomy 32:11, Psalm 91:4, Isaiah 40:11, and Luke 13:34.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase in Matthew 23:39 regarding seeing Jesus again?
options: They will not see Him until they acknowledge 'Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord'
They will see Him immediately after rejection
They will never see Him again
questions.correctAnswer: They will not see Him until they acknowledge 'Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord'
questions.explanation: This verse (Matthew 23:39) points to future recognition of the Messiah and eschatological restoration, reflecting Psalm 118:26, Zechariah 9:9, John 12:13, and Acts 3:19-21.
